historicalDescription: This narrow street was located in the bustling Rialto district, known for its merchants, artisans, and the famous Rialto Bridge. The area was a center of trade and commerce in 15th century Venice.

connection.historicalDescription: Named after the money changers who operated near Rialto, one of Venice's primary financial centers. The cambisti were essential figures in Renaissance Venice's international commerce, exchanging various currencies for merchants and traders in the busy San Zuane area.

Referring to the official weighing scales used to measure goods in the nearby commercial area. The Rialto district was home to merchants who needed accurate measurements for trade, and this bridge would have been near where public scales were maintained by the Republic.

Named for Venice's revolutionary public banking system that operated near Rialto. The Bancogiro, established in 1619, allowed merchants to transfer credits between accounts without physical currency, making it one of the first clearing houses in Europe near San Zuane.

Dedicated to the sensali (brokers) who facilitated trade deals between merchants in the Rialto area. These licensed intermediaries were vital to Venice's commercial system, connecting buyers and sellers while ensuring adherence to the Republic's regulations.

connection.englishName: Bridge of Saint John the Almsgiver
connection.historicalDescription: Named after the nearby church of San Giovanni Elemosinario in the Rialto area. This church was rebuilt after the fire of 1514 that devastated the Rialto district, and the bridge would have connected worshippers to this important parish church.

Referencing the German merchants who maintained a significant presence in Venice's trade network. The Fondaco dei Tedeschi (German trading house) was near Rialto, and this bridge would have been part of the route German merchants took between their quarters and the San Zuane commercial area.

Named for the silk merchants and workshops that operated in this area of Rialto. Venice was a major center for luxury silk trade in the Renaissance, with many artisans processing raw silk into finished textiles near San Zuane.

Named after the commercial court jurors who would have used this route to reach the Rialto courts. The Venetian Republic maintained specialized courts for resolving merchant disputes, staffed by giurati (jurors) with expertise in commercial matters.

Referring to the public warehouses (fontego) where goods were stored near the Rialto contract. These state-controlled storage facilities were crucial to Venice's trade system, ensuring taxation and quality control of merchandise entering the city.

Named for one of Venice's two traditional factions of fishermen and gondoliers. The Nicolotti (followers of San Nicolò) had territories that extended into parts of the Rialto area, and this bridge would have been used by members of this important working-class faction.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the merchants who conducted business in the Rialto contract area, this street would have been home to various traders and vendors who supplied goods to the bustling commercial center.
This street would have housed goldsmiths and jewelers who had workshops in the Rialto area. The concentration of valuable trade in this area required proximity to the commercial heart of Venice.

Named after the bankers who operated in the area, this former canal was filled in to create a street. The Rialto was the financial center of Venice, where many banking families established their operations.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Street of the German Trading House
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named for its proximity to the Fontego dei Tedeschi, the warehouse and residence for German merchants operating in Venice. This important commercial building was near the Rialto Bridge.

This covered passageway would have been frequented by money changers who exchanged foreign currencies for Venetian ducats. Located near San Zuane in Rialto, it served the international merchants in the area.
Named for the silk merchants and traders who sold this valuable commodity. Silk was one of Venice's most important luxury imports, and this street would have featured shops selling silk fabrics.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Paved Street of the Spice Merchants
buildingPoints.streetDescription: One of the first paved streets in the area, it was named after the spice merchants who sold exotic spices from the East. The spice trade was a cornerstone of Venetian commerce in the Rialto area.

Named after the merchants who traded in cotton ('bombaso' in Venetian dialect). Cotton was an important textile import to Venice, and these merchants would have had shops near the commercial center of Rialto.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Filled Canal of the Circulating Bank
buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the Banco Giro, Venice's public bank established in 1619. Though the bank was established after the Renaissance, the name reflects the important financial activities that took place in this area near Rialto.
Named for the brokers who facilitated trade deals between merchants. These middlemen were essential to Venetian commerce in the Rialto contract area, connecting buyers and sellers.
This street housed merchants who sold cloth and textiles. The textile trade was central to Venice's economy, and drapers would have had a significant presence near San Zuane in Rialto.

Named for the tinsmiths who had workshops in this area. These artisans created various tin items for household and commercial use, serving the needs of the Rialto contract and surrounding neighborhood.
Named for its proximity to the fish contract that operated in the Rialto area. This waterside street would have been busy with fishmongers and customers seeking fresh seafood from the lagoon.
Named after the Cinque Savi alla Mercanzia, the five officials who regulated Venetian trade. Their office would have been near this street in the commercial heart of the Rialto area.
Named after a respected craftsman or guild master who would have had a workshop or residence in this small square near San Zuane in Rialto.
Named either after a inn or tavern called 'The Sturgeon' that was located here, or after sturgeon merchants who sold this prized fish. This name reflects the gastronomic commerce of the area.

This covered passageway was named for the mercers (small goods merchants) who sold textiles, ribbons, and haberdashery items. These merchants would have had small shops in the bustling Rialto commercial district.
Named after taverns serving Malvasia (Malmsey), a sweet wine from Greece that was popular in Venice. Wine shops were common in the commercial areas around Rialto to serve merchants and visitors.

This former canal was filled to create a street where butcher shops were located. Keeping the meat contract in a specific area was common practice in Renaissance Venice for sanitation and control purposes.
Named after a notable house sign or tavern called 'Paradise,' this street would have been recognized by this distinctive landmark in the San Zuane in Rialto area.
Another street dedicated to goldsmiths and jewelers, reflecting the concentration of this luxury trade near the commercial center of Rialto where wealthy merchants and nobles would shop.
Named for its proximity to a public warehouse for flour. Food staples were carefully regulated in Venice, and this street would have been near where flour was stored and distributed.
Named after a merchant consortium or business partnership that operated in the area. Business consortiums were common in Renaissance Venice to share risks in trade ventures.
Named after a shop or inn sign depicting a white lion, this street would have been identified by this notable landmark near the San Zuane in Rialto area.
A small courtyard named after the craftsmen who made oars for Venetian boats. These specialized artisans would have had workshops near the commercial center to supply the maritime needs of merchants.
Named for the craftsmen who made spindles for the textile industry. Their proximity to the textile merchants of the Rialto area would have been advantageous for business.
Named after the Procurators of St. Mark, high officials who administered properties. This filled canal could have led to properties or offices administered by these officials in the Rialto area.
Named for a significant warehouse that stored goods for the nearby Rialto contract. Storage facilities were essential to Venice's commercial infrastructure.
This covered passageway led to a gondola ferry crossing point on the Grand Canal. Traghetti were essential for moving between the banks of the canal in the Rialto area.
Named either after a shop sign depicting a serpent or after a winding, snake-like shape of the street itself. Located in the dense urban fabric near San Zuane in Rialto.
One of the first paved streets in the area, leading to an important public or private warehouse (fontego). Its paved status indicates its importance in the commercial network of Rialto.
Named for the booksellers and publishers who had shops here. Venice was a major center of printing and publishing during the Renaissance, with many bookshops near the commercial center.
This poetically named former canal might have been near a church or monastery where contemplation was encouraged, or simply a quiet area amid the busy Rialto district.
Named for the craftsmen who made wooden barrels essential for storing wine, oil, and other liquids. These artisans would have served the merchants of the Rialto contract area.
Named for its proximity to the Church of San Zuane (Saint John) in Rialto. The designation 'vecchia' (old) suggests it was an established street in the earlier development of the area.
Named after bakers who specialized in 'pandoro' or other specialty breads. Food producers would have been scattered throughout the commercial districts to serve workers and residents.
This covered passageway might have been prone to flooding during acqua alta (high water), reflecting Venice's constant negotiation with its lagoon environment even in the commercial heart of Rialto.
Named after a shop sign depicting a black hat or after a hat-maker's shop. Distinctive shop signs were important landmarks in Renaissance Venice, especially in commercial areas like Rialto.
This waterside street would have been where wine boats unloaded their cargo from mainland vineyards. Wine was both an important trade good and daily necessity in Renaissance Venice.
